moves.1. e4 c5 2. d4: I disagree with this move as White ends up losing a tempo after Qxd4. There is the possibility of the Morra gambit.
moves.3... Nc6: Developing with the attack on the queen
moves.4. Qd3 Nf6 5. Bg5 e5: Pins the knight, but better than having doubled pawns on the king side
moves.6. a3 Bc5 7. Nf3 d6 8. b4: Hmm, white is pushing pawns while not fully developed.
moves.8... Bb6 9. b5 Nd4: I was hoping for 10. Nxd4 Bxd4 11. Ra2 Be6 and the rook is trapped
moves.10. Nc3 Bg4 11. Be2 Rc8: Building up on the c3 knight
moves.12. Bxf6 Qxf6 13. Nd5 Qd8 14. c3: playing Rb1 would have been better before this move, in my opinion, as it limits my knight's squares to run to. In any case, I was eyeing the c5 square as a nice outpost for the knight
moves.14... Nb3 15. Rb1 Nc5 16. Qe3 O-O 17. Nx: A bit of an inacuracy...Qa5+ will now win me a pawn
The decision to trade off the queens here is a bad one for white. He ends up with doubled pawns on the e file. The choice, for me, was easy.
moves.22... Qxe3+ 23. fxe3 b6 24. O-O Nb7: Not being able to find a way to get at the e4 pawn, I decided to try for c4 instead.
moves.26... Nxc4 27. Nxg6 hxg6 28. Rfe1: Protecting e3, but I had better plans for the knight
moves.28... Na3: Forking the bishop and rook. White's position is falling apart.
moves.29. Rba1: Ra1?? White's fatal mistake. Loses a bishop and a rook for a knight.
